case_vignette: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. Aside from occasional lower back pain in the last couple of years, he feels well. He had a right-sided myocardial infarction 4 years ago. Currently, he has no shortness of breath and has no anginal symptoms. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking but stopped smoking 10 years ago and does not drink alcohol. His pulse is 59/min, and his blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals 1+ lower extremity edema. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation show no abnormalities. There is no lymphadenopathy. His laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 13.2 g/dL and serum protein of 10.1 g/dL. ECG shows known Q wave abnormalities unchanged since the last ECG one year ago. A serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation is shown.  A) Perform a bone marrow biopsy. B) Perform a serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation. C) D) Perform a CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis. E) Perform a skeletal survey. F) Perform a urine protein electrophoresis. G) Perform a liver function test. H) Perform a renal function test. I) Perform a complete blood count. J) Perform a serum calcium level. K) Perform a serum creatinine level. L) Perform a serum albumin level. M) Perform a serum globulin level. N) Perform a serum iron level. O) Perform a serum vitamin B12 level. P) Perform a serum folate level. Q) Perform a serum magnesium level. R) Perform a serum potassium level. S) Perform a serum sodium level. T) Perform a serum chloride level. U) Perform a serum bicarbonate level. V) Perform a serum phosphorus level. W) Perform a serum alkaline phosphatase level. X) Perform a serum aspartate aminotransferase level. Y) Perform a serum alanine aminotransferase level. Z) Perform a serum gamma-glutamyl transferase level. AA) Perform a serum lactate dehydrogenase level. AB) Perform a serum creatine kinase level. AC) Perform a serum amylase level. AD)
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis?
